title: Georgia House - Day 31 (2026-03-07)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House session transcript:

## Overview
The session featured discussions on the importance of empathy and compassion towards all people, regardless of their background or circumstances. The transcript focused on a speech by Pastor Travis Rutland highlighting the parable of the Good Samaritan and the need to see others as neighbors, not just scenery or machinery.

## Key Actions
No major legislative actions were recorded in the transcript provided.

## Bills Introduced (First Reading)
No new bills were introduced during this session.

## Notable Moments
- Pastor Travis Rutland delivered a speech on the importance of seeing all people as neighbors, not just scenery or machinery, using the parable of the Good Samaritan as an example.
- Rutland spoke about his childhood experiences of praying for the governor and state legislators while growing up.

## Votes
No recorded votes were mentioned in the transcript.

## Attendance
No specific quorum or attendance details were provided.

## Adjournment
The transcript does not mention the time of adjournment or the date of the next scheduled session.

you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you Travis serves as the president of Global Servants. Global Servants is an international nonprofit missions and ministry organization. Global Servants currently has a work in six countries and two continents. He is a native of Georgia. He holds a bachelor's degree and a master's degree from southeastern university. Travis and his wife Courtney have been married since 1997 and they have three sons, Mark Owen and Liam. And our fathers have been friends for a long time and I've known Travis and known Travis's family for many years now and had the great fortune to have him come to Carter'sville to Liberty Square and so we're so blessed to have him. And I'm glad that he was able to come today. So would y'all welcome Pastor Travis Rutland. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Good day. Thank you. Welcome morning. I'm honored and thrilled to be here with you today. I appreciate Matthew's introduction. That was so kind of him. I want to say a special thank you to Speaker Burns for the invitation that is humbling and I'm honored to be here today. When I was a little boy growing up, my dad was actually friends with Governor Joe Frank Harris. And so I remember every time that we drove into Atlanta when we would drive by the Capitol, my dad would always say, we have to pray for the governor. So I grew up as a little boy praying for the folks inside these buildings and I'm honored and excited to be back with you or be here with you today to give you a little thought and to pray over all of you. So I appreciate everything that you do. I'm a proud native of Georgia. As Matthew said, I was born in Atlanta, grew up in Conjures for the most part and I'm thrilled to be here this morning. So I just wanted to give you a quick thought and I want to be mindful of my time. How do we deal with the world around us? How do we relate to the people that we encounter on a regular basis? Following World War II, there was a Polish anthropologist named Alicia Ivanska and she immigrated to the United States following World War II and she began to travel and work at universities write articles in books. I read an interesting article about her. In 1957, she traveled to the Midwest of America to interview farmers for a book that she was writing. And in the process of interviewing these farmers, she said that all of these farmers had broken down their world view into three main categories. That the farmers saw the world around them through the prism of scenery, machinery, and people. So the mountains in the distance, the trees, all those kinds of things, they were this scenery that they took for granted. The tractors, the plows, the tools that they used to farm were machinery and then people were people. And so I was reading that article and it was reminded me of an encounter that Jesus had in his ministry. I won't read the verses, but it's found in the Gospel of Luke in chapter 10. And in that, a man approaches Jesus and he talks to Jesus about how can he inherit eternal life. And Jesus says to man, well, what do you think? And the man says, well, I believe that if you love the Lord your God with all your heart, your mind, and soul and you love your neighbor as yourself. And Jesus says, that's it, that's exactly it. Do that and you'll inherit eternal life. And the man says to Jesus a very intriguing question. He says to him, yes, but who is my neighbor? My feeling is that the man was trying to compartmentalize his life a little bit. He was trying to figure out who did he have to treat as his neighbor. He says to Jesus, yes, but who is my neighbor? And Jesus, as he so often does, does not answer the question. He instead tells a story. And the story that he tells is probably one of the most famous stories that Jesus told us what we know as the parable of the Good Samaritan. In the parable of the Good Samaritan, a man is traveling from Jerusalem to Jericho. He's attacked by thieves, he's beaten, robbed, and left for dead on the side of the road. A priest walks by, sees the man and continues on his way. A Levite walks by and sees the man and continues on his way. And then Jesus tells us in the story that a Samaritan sees the man and stops and helps him bandages his wounds, puts the man on his animal, and takes him to an inn or a hotel for lack of a better word. Takes him to an inn and gives him to an innkeeper and says, take care of this man and I'm going to come back and get him. In that story, Jesus is giving us insight into how we relate to others. For most of us, most of the time, the people that we see are nothing more than scenery. The folks in the restaurants dining next to us, the people walking through parking lots, the homeless guys that we see at the stoplight, they are nothing more than the scenery. They are extras in the movie starring us. In the same way that Tom Cruise doesn't hang out with extras on his movie set, we don't either. This is the Travis Rutland movie and I'm not interested in hanging out with the scenery, with the extras. But the fact of the matter is, they are not mountains far in the distance. They are real people with real needs and real problems. Now, I know what you're saying to yourself, do I have to help every person that I walk through past in the parking lot? I'm not suggesting that. What I am saying is that we have become conditioned, like the priest and the Levite, to ignore the suffering of the people around us. They both saw the man lying by the side of the road, and they said to themselves, he is nothing more than scenery, and they continued on their way. But the world around us has real needs and real problems. Now, pivot away from the crowds, and instead deal with the people that we look at and interact with on a more regular basis. The waitress at the restaurant, the checkout girl at the grocery store. If you can find a grocery store that still has a checkout person, usually we have to do it ourselves now, but you have to check out girl, waitress, teacher, pastor, politicians, all of these, we interact with these people. And the problem is we begin to see them as the farmers that Alicia Ivanska interviewed. We begin to see them as nothing more than machinery. They are machines that are designed to make, what are machines designed to do? Make our lives easier. So what we begin to do is see them, not as people, but as simply a cog in the machine that makes my life simpler. So we're standing at the Walmart and the girl that's checking us out scans the same item three times. She gets our change wrong. She puts the bread in the bottom of the bag and it gets crushed. And we say to herself, she's such an idiot. What's wrong with this girl? But the thing is, maybe she's not an idiot at all. Maybe her mother is dying. And when she gets off work, she's gonna go to an assisted living facility and hold her mom's hand as she passes away. But see, we have no concept of that because that girl is not a person to us. She is simply a cog in the machine that makes our life easier. We cannot see people as simply scenery and machinery. So what is the solution? Jesus gives us the solution as the story ends. The story ends and Jesus says to the man, who was the man who was robbed, who was a neighbor to him. And the man responds and he says, the one who showed him mercy. And Jesus says, go and do likewise. Do you see that? So many of us want to shrink who we think of is our neighbor. We want to shrink it as the man, who's my neighbor? Jesus expands our understanding of who our neighbor is. We want to say it's just the people who believe what I believe. It's just the people who think like I do. It's just the people who vote like I do. But that is not what Jesus is saying to us. Jesus is saying expand your worldview. The whole world out there, that is your neighbor. Go and do likewise. That's what I would encourage everybody here in this house and anywhere that's watching online or anything else. The people around us are not scenery and they are not machinery. They are real people with real needs and real problems. And we are called to show them love, mercy, and forgiveness. Jesus, we say to Jesus, who is our neighbor? Jesus says, the whole world is, go and do likewise. If you will, stand with me and join me in prayer. God, we come to you right now. I thank you for every man and woman in this chamber. I ask that you would bless them, that you would give them wisdom and your guidance. They are making important decisions that affect the people of Georgia and I ask that you would be with them, that you would guide them and direct them, give them your wisdom, your knowledge on all things. I intercede for them, I ask that you bless them. You bless their families. Everything that they put their hand towards that you would bless. Be with them, guide and direct them. We thank you for all your many blessings. In Jesus, powerful name we pray. Amen and amen. Amen. All right. I pledge glad that the allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic. Thank you, brother Travis, for that message. Doorkeepers, you may unlock the doors. A resolution, recognizing and commending the Duffy Warren County Unit on being named the Georgia Forestry Commission 2023, North Georgia Unit of the Year, the Barrier County Unit on being named the 2023 South Georgia Unit of the Year, Forest Protection Area 9 being named the 2023 Forest Protection Area of the Year, and Jason McMullan on being named the 2023 Forester of the Year. Thank you, Mr. Clerk. We will now recognize Chair Lady Penny Hausten to speak to the resolution. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. It is an honor for me to be here today to recognize two units and a person who's done so much for the state to protect you. Of course, it's really special since one of these people I'm recognizing they're from Barrier County where I'm from, so it makes it even more special because they really protect all of us. And it's like a wise man that sits on the front, represents him, James Persia told me that when a fire comes, these men run toward the fire, not away from the fire like we do. And we do appreciate that because they do protect us and protect our forest land. And as you probably know, Georgia is one of the global leaders in timber in this country. And also, I was surprised to learn that 22,000 acres are privately owned timber land are in our state. And these men protect all of it. And we just want to show appreciation and honor them. And first of all, there's another county representative, Jackson, represents MacDuffy and Warren County. And MacDuffy and Warren County's unit was named the Georgia Forestry Commission, 2023 Georgia Unit of the Year. And also was named for the Georgia, South Georgia Unit of the Year was the Barrier County Fire Department. And the 2023 Forest Protection Area of the Year was also named. And that was Area Number 9 of which Mayor and County is a member and so is Camilla. And I thought I'd point that out to you. And also, I would like to tell you that we have James McMullen here. And he's been named the 2023 Forestry of the Year. And they protect us, they protect our forestry. And these people would name this because of their leadership and their dedication to protect people in forest lands. And I want to say thank you. And if you get a chance, please come speak with them. And I'd like to ask our Forest Commission Tim Lottermell to come say a few words. Thank you, Madam Chair. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. It is a tremendous pleasure to be here. And I'll be brief. I know you've got a lot on your calendar and on your schedule today. I do want to acknowledge that we've got some of our other great employees up in the balcony there. I'd like for them to stay in and make them give them and our folks up here on the podium around the applause. If you will, Mr. Speaker, I would just take a brief moment to say many of you in this house recognize and know that my experience came from the private sector. I've been the Director of had the opportunity to serve underneath Governor Kim. The pleasure to serve him as the Director for the Georgia Forestry Commission now for three years. And one of the lessons, and I think it's pertinent to the day, one of the lessons that I have learned coming from the private sector and getting the work with these great men and women at the Georgia Forestry Commission is just their willingness to serve. Their willingness to serve in communities where they live, their willingness to serve in communities that need their help. Just this past year, the Barian County Office and the Area 9 responded to the hurricane that came through Valdosta. We are generally one of the first on the ground with chainsaws, clearing roads for power companies and for them to get back into restore power. The other thing that makes me really proud and I want to point out to this body is that when we have time here slow and we don't have an active fire season, our state is known around the country to have some of the best and brightest to pick up, get away from their families, leave their communities and go serve other places like Texas, California. Any state where there may be a wildfire, we're some of the first to show up. Right now we have five in Oklahoma and we have one serving on an overhead team in Texas, putting out wildfires. I often get asked, why don't we have major wildfires here in Georgia? I think there's several reasons and I'll be brief. A lot of it is that our properties here in Georgia, 91% of our forest, that 22 million acres, is owned by private forest landowners. Our agency recognizes that, they understand that's an investment account, that's a child's college education account, that's a wedding, that's a retirement account for a landowner, for forest landowner. And we don't have fires in Georgia because we take responding and putting fires out serious in our state. Our average response time to a wildfire is 24 minutes. Our wildfire size in our state is five acres. I would put that up against any other state in the union. So thank you for taking the time to recognize these young men and women and for the work they do. I can promise you they're servants for our state and they get up every day and go to work for you hard and do their job with great pride and great honor. So thank you for recognizing us. And thank you so much for the job you're doing. And the changes you brought to our area. Thank you. Thank you. Appreciate you. I'm away my glasses. Sam, let's go. The city of Atlanta enjoys an excellent working relationship with many of our state partners especially when it comes to one of the most important issues for us and that is public safety. We have had an outstanding set of support from the GBI the Georgia State Patrol and other state agencies as we work together to reduce crime in and around Atlanta. These partnerships have helped us to significantly reduce our crime numbers in 2023. In fact the city of Atlanta had the third highest drop in homicides than any other city in the United States. We ended the year when citywide major crimes against people down by 15% homicides down by 21% that includes double-digit drops in aggravated assaults, shootings and rapes. The horrible crime of rape was down 51% in the city of Atlanta last year. All of this underscores our work to create a safer environment for the people who live and work in the city of Atlanta and I know that's a common goal for all of us. Another common goal that we share is figuring out how to bring more affordable housing options to the people that are in this city and in the entire state of Georgia. The lack of affordable housing, that challenge is not just in Atlanta challenge, that's a challenge for the entire state and that's why I'm so proud to being a partnership with Commissioner Chris Nunn here who's up in the balcony. He is the Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs that helps us so much. It is especially challenging as we work to house the unsheltered residents of our communities. But luckily for us, again, we have dedicated partners, a rapid housing effort that started with an offer of shipping containers from our state partners at GEMA has led to what we call the melody and nearly 40 previously unsheltered people now have a clean and safe place to lay their heads at night. Thank you. Every one of these people, they have a story and I'll just give you one of them. His name is George. He's a truck driver. George trained to be a truck driver. He has a CDL but then he had a stroke and as he was on his way to Grady Hospital, he had another one and he ultimately ended up having five strokes in a very short amount of time. So he couldn't drive trucks anymore and therefore he lost his job but ultimately he ended up losing his home. Here's a guy who tried to make all the right choices, trained to do what he loves. He paid his bills and all it took was a medical emergency to drive him into the streets of Atlanta. We had people like George and mine when we launched this rapid housing initiative and called this one the melody. When you start putting a face on the problem and you hear the stories, you realize that some of the people who worked the hardest and tried to do the best thing, they can find themselves upside down at the end of the day.
